CAT Theory，meow~

# The category of sets

# Isomorphism

Definition(Isomorphism)

Let XXX and YYY be sets. A function f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y is called an isomorphism, denoted X→≅YX\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow}YX→≅Y, if there exists a function g:Y→Xg:Y\rightarrow Xg:Y→X such that g∘f=idXg\circ f=id_Xg∘f=idX​ and f∘g=idYf\circ g=id_Yf∘g=idY​.

We also say that fff is invertible and we say that ggg is the inverse of fff. If there exists an isomorphism X→≅YX\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow} YX→≅Y we say that XXX and YYY are isomorphic sets and may write X≅YX\cong YX≅Y.

Lemma:

  • ∀A,A≅A\forall A,A\cong A∀A,A≅A.
  • ∀A,B,A≅B⇔B≅A\forall A,B,A\cong B\Leftrightarrow B\cong A∀A,B,A≅B⇔B≅A.
  • ∀A,B,C,(A≅B∧B≅C)⇒A≅C\forall A,B,C,(A\cong B\wedge B\cong C)\Rightarrow A\cong C∀A,B,C,(A≅B∧B≅C)⇒A≅C.
  • ∀A,B,A≅B⇒∣A∣=∣B∣\forall A,B,A\cong B\Rightarrow |A|=|B|∀A,B,A≅B⇒∣A∣=∣B∣.

# Commutative diagrams

We say this is a diagram of sets if each of A,B,CA,B,CA,B,C is a set and each of f,g,hf,g,hf,g,h is a function. We say this diagram commutes if g∘f=hg\circ f=hg∘f=h.

In this case we refer to it as a commutative triangle of sets. However, the statement here is not precise enough to be a definition.

If g∘f=i∘hg\circ f = i\circ hg∘f=i∘h, then we refer to it as a commutative square of sets.

To say that the diagram commutes would say that every approach gives the same result. (Each approach is a combination of functions).

# Ologs

Example:

We represent each type as a box containing a singular indefinite noun phrase…

The text in the box should:

  • begin with the word “a” or “an”.
  • refer to a distinction made and recognizable by the olog’s author.
  • refer to a distinction for which instances can be documented.
  • declare all variables in a compound structure.

We consider aspects as functions. for example:

we can say “a woman has an aspect of being a person”, and “a molecule has an aspect (where we call mass usually) of a positive real number.”

However, “a person has a child” is not a valid aspect, since there exists people who don’t have children.

Remark: since a father can have many children, so we write a  child→hasa  fathera\; child\stackrel{has}{\rightarrow}a\;fatherachild→hasafather instead of a  father→hasa  childa\;father\stackrel{has}{\rightarrow} a\;childafather→hasachild.

A path in an olog is a head-to-tail sequence of arrows. The number of arrows is the length of the path.

We all know that “the woman in parents is called mother” and “mother is the woman in parents” (though it sounds weird), so the two paths are equivalent, the triangle is commutative. And the checker-mark √ in the region is bounded by the two paths.

# Products and coproducts

Definition(products)

Let XXX and YYY be sets. The product of XXX and YYY, denoted X×YX\times YX×Y, is defined as

X×Y={(x,y)∣x∈X,y∈Y}X\times Y =\{(x,y)|x\in X,y\in Y\} X×Y={(x,y)∣x∈X,y∈Y}

There are two natural project functions π1:X×Y→X\pi_1:X\times Y\rightarrow Xπ1​:X×Y→X and π2:X×Y→Y\pi_2:X\times Y\rightarrow Yπ2​:X×Y→Y.

Now we can construct more examples of non-commutative diagrams:

Lemma(Universal property for product)

Let XXX and YYY be sets. For any set AAA and functions f:A→Xf:A\rightarrow Xf:A→X and g:A→Yg:A\rightarrow Yg:A→Y, there exists a unique function A→X×YA\rightarrow X\times YA→X×Y such that the following diagram commutes.

We may write the unique function as ⟨f,g⟩:A→X×Y\langle f,g\rangle:A\rightarrow X\times Y⟨f,g⟩:A→X×Y. And obviously, ⟨f,g⟩(a)=(f(a),g(a))\langle f,g\rangle(a)=(f(a),g(a))⟨f,g⟩(a)=(f(a),g(a)).

Definition(coproducts)

Let XXX and YYY be sets. The coproduct of XXX and YYY, denoted X⊔YX\sqcup YX⊔Y, is defined as the “disjoint union” of XXX and YYY. If an element is both in XXX and YYY, then we need to copy it in X⊔YX\sqcup YX⊔Y so we can distinguish where each of it comes from.

There are two natural project functions i1:X→X⊔Yi_1:X\rightarrow X\sqcup Yi1​:X→X⊔Y and i2:Y→X⊔Yi_2:Y \rightarrow X\sqcup Yi2​:Y→X⊔Y.

Example:

{a,b}⊔{a,c}={i1a,b,i2a,c}\{a,b\}\sqcup \{a,c\}=\{i_1a,b,i_2a,c\} {a,b}⊔{a,c}={i1​a,b,i2​a,c}

Lemma(Universal property for coproduct)

Let XXX and YYY be sets. For any set AAA and functions f:X→Af:X\rightarrow Af:X→A and g:Y→Ag:Y\rightarrow Ag:Y→A, there exists a unique function X⊔Y→AX\sqcup Y\rightarrow AX⊔Y→A such that the following diagram commutes.

We may write the unique functions as

{fg:X⊔Y→A{fg(m)={f(x)if  m=i1xg(y)if  m=i2y\begin{cases}f\\g\end{cases}:X\sqcup Y\rightarrow A\\ \begin{cases}f\\g\end{cases}(m)=\begin{cases}f(x)&if\;m=i_1x\\g(y)&if\;m=i_2y\end{cases} {fg​:X⊔Y→A{fg​(m)={f(x)g(y)​ifm=i1​xifm=i2​y​

# Finite limits in Set

Definition(Pullback)

Suppose given the diagram of sets and functions below:

Its fiber product is the set

X×ZY:={(x,w,y)∣f(x)=w=g(y)}X\times_Z Y:=\{(x,w,y)|f(x)=w=g(y)\} X×Z​Y:={(x,w,y)∣f(x)=w=g(y)}

There are obvious projections π1:X×ZY→X\pi_1:X\times_Z Y\rightarrow Xπ1​:X×Z​Y→X and π2:X×ZY→Y\pi_2:X\times_Z Y\rightarrow Yπ2​:X×Z​Y→Y. Note that if W=X×ZYW=X\times_Z YW=X×Z​Y then the diagram

commutes. So given the setup diagram we define the pullback of XXX and YYY over ZZZ to be any set WWW for which we have an isomorphism W→≅X×ZYW\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow} X\times_Z YW→≅X×Z​Y.

The corner symbol ⌟\lrcorner┘ indicates that WWW is the pullback.

Lemma(Universal property for pullback)

Suppose given the diagram as below:

For any set AAA and commutative solid arrow diagram as below (i.e. t∘f=u∘gt\circ f=u\circ gt∘f=u∘g)

there exists a unique arrow ⟨f,f⟩Z:A→X×ZY\langle f,f\rangle_Z:A\rightarrow X\times_Z Y⟨f,f⟩Z​:A→X×Z​Y making everything commute.

Definition(Preimage)

Let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a function and y∈Yy\in Yy∈Y an element. The preimage of yyy under fff, denoted f−1(y)f^{-1}(y)f−1(y), is the subset f−1(y):={x∈X∣f(x)=y}f^{-1}(y):=\{x\in X|f(x)=y\}f−1(y):={x∈X∣f(x)=y}. If Y′⊆YY'\subseteq YY′⊆Y is any subset, the preimage of Y′Y'Y′ under fff, denoted f−1(Y′)f^{-1}(Y')f−1(Y′), is the subset f−1(Y′)={x∈X∣f(x)∈Y′}f^{-1}(Y')=\{x\in X|f(x)\in Y'\}f−1(Y′)={x∈X∣f(x)∈Y′}.

Proposition: Consider the diagram below:

where B′≅B×CC′B'\cong B\times_C C'B′≅B×C​C′ is a pullback. Then there is an isomorphism A×BB′≅A×CC′A\times_B B'\cong A\times_C C'A×B​B′≅A×C​C′. Said another way,

A×B(B×CC′)≅A×CC′A\times_B(B\times_C C')\cong A\times_C C' A×B​(B×C​C′)≅A×C​C′

Exercise: Consider the diagram on the left below, where both squares commute.

Let W=X×ZYW=X\times_Z YW=X×Z​Y and W′=X′×ZY′W'=X'\times_Z Y'W′=X′×Z​Y′, and form the diagram to the right. Use the universal property of fiber products to construct a map W→W′W\rightarrow W'W→W′ such that all squares commute.

Solution:

Definition

Given sets AAA and BBB, a span on AAA and BBB is a set RRR together with functions f:R→Af:R\rightarrow Af:R→A and g:R→Bg:R\rightarrow Bg:R→B.

Definition

Let A,BA,BA,B and CCC be sets, and let A←fR→gCA\stackrel{f}{\leftarrow} R\stackrel{g}{\rightarrow}CA←fR→gC and B←f′R′→g′CB\stackrel{f'}{\leftarrow} R'\stackrel{g'}{\rightarrow}CB←f′R′→g′C be spans. Their composite span is given by the fiber product R×BR′R\times_B R'R×B​R′ as in the diagram below:

Let’s look at a example of span, which may be a little confusing but reveals the relationship between matrix plus and span.

Let AAA and BBB be sets and let A←R→BA\leftarrow R\rightarrow BA←R→B be a span. By the universal property of products, we have a unique map R→pA×BR\stackrel{p}{\rightarrow} A\times BR→pA×B.

We make a matrix of natural numbers out of this data as follows. The set of rows is AAA, the set of columns is BBB. For elements a∈Aa\in Aa∈A and b∈Bb\in Bb∈B, the (a,b)(a,b)(a,b)-entry is the cardinality of its preimage, ∣p−1(a,b)∣|p^{-1}(a,b)|∣p−1(a,b)∣, i.e. the number of elements in RRR that are sent by ppp to (a,b)(a,b)(a,b). For example, if R={(1,1),(1,2),(2,1),(2,2)}R=\{(1,1),(1,2),(2,1),(2,2)\}R={(1,1),(1,2),(2,1),(2,2)} and p(a,b)=(a,b)p(a,b)=(a,b)p(a,b)=(a,b), then we can make the matrix (1111)\begin{pmatrix}1&1\\1&1\end{pmatrix}(11​11​).

Given two spans A←R→BA\leftarrow R\rightarrow BA←R→B and A←R′→BA\leftarrow R'\rightarrow BA←R′→B, by the universal property of coproducts we have a unique span A←R⊔R′→BA\leftarrow R\sqcup R'\rightarrow BA←R⊔R′→B making the diagram commute. The matrix corresponding to this new span will be the sum of the two matrices corresponding to span RRR and R′R'R′.

Eq(f,g):={x∈X∣f(x)=g(x)}Eq(f,g):=\{x\in X|f(x)=g(x)\} Eq(f,g):={x∈X∣f(x)=g(x)}

and where ppp is the canonical inclusion.

# Finite colimits in Set

Definition(Pullout)

Suppose given the diagram of sets and functions below:

Its fiber sum, denoted X⊔WYX\sqcup_W YX⊔W​Y, is defined as the quotient of X⊔W⊔YX\sqcup W\sqcup YX⊔W⊔Y by the equivalence relation ∼\sim∼ generated by w∼f(w)w\sim f(w)w∼f(w) and w∼g(w)w\sim g(w)w∼g(w) for all w∈Ww\in Ww∈W.

X⊔WY:=(X⊔W⊔Y)/∼X\sqcup_W Y:=(X\sqcup W\sqcup Y)/\sim X⊔W​Y:=(X⊔W⊔Y)/∼

where ∀w∈W,w∼f(w)\forall w\in W,w\sim f(w)∀w∈W,w∼f(w) and w∼g(w)w\sim g(w)w∼g(w).

There are obvious inclusions i1:X→X⊔WYi_1:X\rightarrow X\sqcup_W Yi1​:X→X⊔W​Y and i2:X→X⊔WYi_2:X\rightarrow X\sqcup_W Yi2​:X→X⊔W​Y. The following diagram commutes:

We define the pushout of XXX and YYY over WWW to be any set ZZZ for which we have an isomorphism Z→≅X⊔WYZ\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow} X\sqcup_W YZ→≅X⊔W​Y. The corner symbol ⌜\ulcorner┌ indicates that ZZZ is the pushout.

Example: W={1,2},X={0,1,2,3},Y={0,1,2,3,4}W=\{1,2\},X=\{0,1,2,3\},Y=\{0,1,2,3,4\}W={1,2},X={0,1,2,3},Y={0,1,2,3,4} and f(x)=x+1,g(x)=xf(x)=x+1,g(x)=xf(x)=x+1,g(x)=x. Then

W⊔X⊔Y={1W,2W,0X,1X,2X,3X,0Y,1Y,2Y,3Y,4Y}W\sqcup X\sqcup Y = \{1_W,2_W,0_X,1_X,2_X,3_X,0_Y,1_Y,2_Y,3_Y,4_Y\} W⊔X⊔Y={1W​,2W​,0X​,1X​,2X​,3X​,0Y​,1Y​,2Y​,3Y​,4Y​}

since we have

2X=f(1W)∼1W∼g(1W)=1Y3X=f(2W)∼2W∼g(2W)=2Y2_X=f(1_W)\sim 1_W\sim g(1_W)=1_Y\\ 3_X=f(2_W)\sim 2_W\sim g(2_W)=2_Y 2X​=f(1W​)∼1W​∼g(1W​)=1Y​3X​=f(2W​)∼2W​∼g(2W​)=2Y​

So the fiber sum is:

(X⊔W⊔Y)/∼={{0X}{1X}{1W,2X,1Y}{2W,3X,2Y}{0Y}{3Y}{4Y}}(X\sqcup W\sqcup Y)/\sim\\ =\{\\ \{0_X\}\\ \{1_X\}\\ \{1_W,2_X,1_Y\}\\ \{2_W,3_X,2_Y\}\\ \{0_Y\}\\ \{3_Y\}\\ \{4_Y\}\\ \} (X⊔W⊔Y)/∼={{0X​}{1X​}{1W​,2X​,1Y​}{2W​,3X​,2Y​}{0Y​}{3Y​}{4Y​}}

# Other notions

Definition(Retractions)

Suppose we have a function f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y and a function g:Y→Xg:Y\rightarrow Xg:Y→X such that g∘f=idXg\circ f=id_Xg∘f=idX​. In this case we call fff a retract section and we call ggg a retract projection.

Notation: Sometimes we use BA:=HomSet(A,B)B^A:=Hom_{Set}(A,B)BA:=HomSet​(A,B) to denote the set of functions from AAA to BBB.

Proposition(Currying). Let AAA denote a set. For any sets X,YX,YX,Y there is a bijection:

ϕ:HomSet(X×A,Y)→≅HomSet(X,YA)\phi:Hom_{Set}(X\times A,Y)\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow}Hom_{Set}(X,Y^A) ϕ:HomSet​(X×A,Y)→≅HomSet​(X,YA)

Proof: Suppose given f:X×A→Yf:X\times A\rightarrow Yf:X×A→Y, Define ϕ(f):X→YA\phi(f):X\rightarrow Y^Aϕ(f):X→YA as follows:

  • for any x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, let ϕ(f)(x):A→Y\phi(f)(x):A\rightarrow Yϕ(f)(x):A→Y as follows:
    • for any a∈Aa\in Aa∈A, let ϕ(f)(x)(a):=f(x,a)\phi(f)(x)(a):=f(x,a)ϕ(f)(x)(a):=f(x,a).

we now construct inverse, ψ:HomSet(X,YA)→HomSet(X×A,Y)\psi:Hom_{Set}(X,Y^A)\rightarrow Hom_{Set}(X\times A,Y)ψ:HomSet​(X,YA)→HomSet​(X×A,Y). Suppose given g:X→YAg:X\rightarrow Y^Ag:X→YA. Define ψ(g):X×A→Y\psi(g):X\times A\rightarrow Yψ(g):X×A→Y as follows:

  • for any pair (x,a)∈X×A(x,a)\in X\times A(x,a)∈X×A let ψ(g)(x,a):=g(x)(a)\psi(g)(x,a):=g(x)(a)ψ(g)(x,a):=g(x)(a).

Then ψ∘ϕ:HomSet(X×A,Y)→HomSet(X×A,Y)\psi\circ\phi:Hom_{Set}(X\times A,Y)\rightarrow Hom_{Set}(X\times A,Y)ψ∘ϕ:HomSet​(X×A,Y)→HomSet​(X×A,Y).

(ψ∘ϕ)(f)(x,a)=ψ(ϕ(f))(x,a)=ψ(g)(x,a)=g(x)(a)=ϕ(f)(x)(a)=f(x,a)(ϕ∘ψ)(g)(x)(a)=ϕ(ψ(g))(x)(a)=ψ(g)(x,a)=g(x)(a)(\psi\circ\phi)(f)(x,a)=\psi(\phi(f))(x,a)=\psi(g)(x,a)\\ =g(x)(a)=\phi(f)(x)(a)=f(x,a)\\ (\phi\circ\psi)(g)(x)(a)=\phi(\psi(g))(x)(a)=\psi(g)(x,a)=g(x)(a) (ψ∘ϕ)(f)(x,a)=ψ(ϕ(f))(x,a)=ψ(g)(x,a)=g(x)(a)=ϕ(f)(x)(a)=f(x,a)(ϕ∘ψ)(g)(x)(a)=ϕ(ψ(g))(x)(a)=ψ(g)(x,a)=g(x)(a)

So

(ψ∘ϕ)(f)=f(ϕ∘ψ)(g)=g(\psi\circ\phi)(f)=f\\ (\phi\circ\psi)(g)=g (ψ∘ϕ)(f)=f(ϕ∘ψ)(g)=g

Proposition: Let’s denote A⊔BA\sqcup BA⊔B with A+BA+BA+B. Then:

A+0‾≅AA+B≅B+A(A+B)+C≅A+(B+C)A×0‾≅0‾A×1‾≅AA×B≅B×A(A×B)×C≅A×(B×C)A×(B+C)≅(A×B)+(A×C)A0‾≅1A1‾≅A0‾A≅0‾1‾A≅1‾AB+C≅AB×AC(AB)C≅AB×CA+\underline{0}\cong A\\ A+B\cong B+A\\ (A+B)+C\cong A+(B+C)\\ A\times\underline{0}\cong \underline{0}\\ A\times\underline{1}\cong A\\ A\times B\cong B\times A\\ (A\times B)\times C\cong A\times(B\times C)\\ A\times(B+C)\cong(A\times B)+(A\times C)\\ A^{\underline{0}}\cong 1\\ A^{\underline{1}}\cong A\\ \underline{0}^A\cong\underline{0}\\ \underline{1}^A\cong\underline{1}\\ A^{B+C}\cong A^B\times A^C\\ (A^B)^C\cong A^{B\times C} A+0​≅AA+B≅B+A(A+B)+C≅A+(B+C)A×0​≅0​A×1​≅AA×B≅B×A(A×B)×C≅A×(B×C)A×(B+C)≅(A×B)+(A×C)A0​≅1A1​≅A0​A≅0​1​A≅1​AB+C≅AB×AC(AB)C≅AB×C

Special case: 0‾0‾=HomSet(∅,∅)=∅\underline{0}^{\underline{0}}= Hom_{Set}(\emptyset,\emptyset)=\emptyset0​0​=HomSet​(∅,∅)=∅.

Example: For any sets A,BA,BA,B, let’s consider the function ev:BA×A→Bev:B^A\times A\rightarrow Bev:BA×A→B. ev(f,a)=f(a)ev(f,a)=f(a)ev(f,a)=f(a).

specially, ev:5‾3‾×3‾→5‾ev:\underline{5}^{\underline{3}}\times\underline{3}\rightarrow\underline{5}ev:5​3​×3​→5​. Since it’s not an isomorphism, so the corresponding arithmetic expression is not equality. However, 575‾→5‾\underline{575}\rightarrow\underline{5}575​→5​ seems weird and meaningless.

Definition

Let VVV be a set and let P(V)\mathbb{P}(V)P(V) be its powerset. A subset X⊆P(V)X\subseteq\mathbb{P}(V)X⊆P(V) is called downward-closed if, for every u∈Xu\in Xu∈X and every u′⊆uu'\subseteq uu′⊆u, we have u′∈Xu'\in Xu′∈X. We say that XXX contains all atoms if for every v∈Vv\in Vv∈V the singleton set {v}\{v\}{v} is an element of XXX.

A simplicial complex is a pair (V,X)(V,X)(V,X) where VVV is a set and X⊆P(V)X\subseteq\mathbb{P}(V)X⊆P(V) is a downward-closed subset that contains all atoms. The elements of XXX are called simplices. We have a function X→NX\rightarrow\mathbb{N}X→N sending each simplex to its cardinality. The set of simplices with cardinality n+1n+1n+1 is denoted as XnX_nXn​. Since XXX contains all atoms, so X0≅VX_0\cong VX0​≅V. Sometimes we call 0-simplices vertices and 1-simplices edges.

Example: let nnn be a natural number and V=n+1‾V=\underline{n+1}V=n+1​. Define the n-simplex denoted Δn\Delta^nΔn to be (V,P(V))(V,\mathbb{P}(V))(V,P(V)), obviously P(V)\mathbb{P}(V)P(V) is downward-closed and contains all atoms.

We can draw Δ0,Δ1,Δ2,Δ3\Delta^0,\Delta^1,\Delta^2,\Delta^3Δ0,Δ1,Δ2,Δ3 as follows:

Definition

Define the subobject classifier for Set, denoted Ω\OmegaΩ, to be the set Ω:={True,False}\Omega:=\{True,False\}Ω:={True,False}, together with the function {♡}→Ω\{\heartsuit\}\rightarrow\Omega{♡}→Ω sending the unique element to True.

Proposition: Let BBB be a set. There is an isomorphism

ϕ:HomSet(B,Ω)→≅P(B)\phi:Hom_{Set}(B,\Omega)\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow}\mathbb{P}(B) ϕ:HomSet​(B,Ω)→≅P(B)

Proof:

Definition

Let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a function. We say that fff is surjective if, for all y∈Yy\in Yy∈Y there exists some x∈Xx\in Xx∈X such that f(x)=yf(x)=yf(x)=y. We say that fff is injective if, for all x∈Xx\in Xx∈X and all x′∈Xx'\in Xx′∈X with f(x)=f(x′)f(x)=f(x')f(x)=f(x′) we have x=x′x=x'x=x′.

Definition

Let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a function. We say that fff is a monomorphism if for all sets AAA and pairs of functions ggg, g′:A→Xg':A\rightarrow Xg′:A→X,

if f∘g=f∘g′f\circ g=f\circ g'f∘g=f∘g′ then g=g′g=g'g=g′.

We say that fff is an epimorphism if for all sets BBB and pairs of functions h,h′:Y→Bh,h':Y\rightarrow Bh,h′:Y→B,

if h∘f=h∘f′h\circ f=h\circ f'h∘f=h∘f′ then h=h′h=h'h=h′.

Proposition: Let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a function. Then fff is injective if and only if it is a monomorphism; fff is surjective if and only if it is an epimorphism.

Proposition: Let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a monomorphism. Then for any function g:A→Yg:A\rightarrow Yg:A→Y, the top map f′:X×YA→Af':X\times_Y A\rightarrow Af′:X×Y​A→A in the diagram

is a monomorphism.

Proof: Consider the diagram:

B is an arbitrary set and we have

f′∘m=f′∘nf'\circ m=f'\circ n f′∘m=f′∘n

we need to prove that m=nm=nm=n. Firstly we construct two morphism

q=g′∘mr=g′∘nq=g'\circ m\\ r=g'\circ n q=g′∘mr=g′∘n

Then

f∘q=f∘g′∘m=g∘f′∘m=g∘f′∘n=f∘g′∘n=f∘rf\circ q = f\circ g'\circ m=g\circ f'\circ m=g\circ f'\circ n = f\circ g'\circ n=f\circ r f∘q=f∘g′∘m=g∘f′∘m=g∘f′∘n=f∘g′∘n=f∘r

since fff is a monomorphism, so q=rq=rq=r. Due to the universal property of pullback, there is a unique morphism B→X×YAB\rightarrow X\times_Y AB→X×Y​A. So m=nm=nm=n.

Remark: if the morphism from BBB to AAA and from BBB to XXX is unique (f′∘m=f′∘nf'\circ m=f'\circ nf′∘m=f′∘n and q=rq=rq=r) then the morphism from BBB to X×YAX\times_Y AX×Y​A is unique.

Definition

A multiset is a sequence X:=(E,B,π)X:=(E,B,\pi)X:=(E,B,π) where EEE and BBB are sets and π:E→B\pi:E\rightarrow Bπ:E→B is a surjective function. We refer to EEE as the set of element instances of XXX, we refer to b as the set of element names of XXX and we refer to π\piπ as the naming function for XXX. Given an element name x∈Bx\in Bx∈B, let π−1(x)⊆E\pi^{-1}(x)\subseteq Eπ−1(x)⊆E be the preimage; the number of elements in π−1(x)\pi^{-1}(x)π−1(x) is called the multiplicity of xxx.

Example: E={1,2,3,4,5}E=\{1,2,3,4,5\}E={1,2,3,4,5}, B={a,b,c}B=\{a,b,c\}B={a,b,c} ,

π(1)=a,π(2)=aπ(3)=bπ(4)=c,π(5)=c\pi(1)=a,\pi(2)=a\\ \pi(3)=b\\ \pi(4)=c,\pi(5)=c π(1)=a,π(2)=aπ(3)=bπ(4)=c,π(5)=c

then it is somehow representing multiset {a,a,b,c,c}\{a,a,b,c,c\}{a,a,b,c,c}.

Suppose that X=(E,B,π)X=(E,B,\pi)X=(E,B,π) and X′=(E′,B′,π′)X'=(E',B',\pi')X′=(E′,B′,π′) are multisets. A mapping from XXX to YYY, denoted f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y, consists of a pair (f1,f0)(f_1,f_0)(f1​,f0​) such that f1:E→E′f_1:E\rightarrow E'f1​:E→E′ and f0:B→B′f_0:B\rightarrow B'f0​:B→B′ are functions and such that the following diagram commutes:

Definition(Relative set)

Let BBB be a set. A relative set over BBB, or simply a set over BBB, is a pair (E,π)(E,\pi)(E,π) such that EEE is a set and π:E→B\pi:E\rightarrow Bπ:E→B is a function. A mapping of relative sets over BBB, denoted f:(E,B)→(E′,B′)f:(E,B)\rightarrow(E',B')f:(E,B)→(E′,B′), is a function f:E→E′f:E\rightarrow E'f:E→E′ such that the triangle below commutes, i.e. π=π′∘f\pi=\pi'\circ fπ=π′∘f.

Definition(Indexed set)

Let AAA be a set. An AAA-indexed set is a collection of sets SaS_aSa​, one for each element a∈Aa\in Aa∈A; for now we denote this by (Sa)a∈A(S_a)_{a\in A}(Sa​)a∈A​. (fa)a∈A:(Sa)a∈A→(Sa′)a∈A(f_a)_{a\in A}:(S_a)_{a\in A}\rightarrow (S_a')_{a\in A} (fa​)a∈A​:(Sa​)a∈A​→(Sa′​)a∈A​

is a collection of functions fa:Sa→Sa′f_a:S_a\rightarrow S_a'fa​:Sa​→Sa′​, one for each element a∈Aa\in Aa∈A.

# Categories and functors

# Monoids

Definition(Monoid)

A monoid is a sequence (M,e,∗)(M,e,*)(M,e,∗), where MMM is a set, e∈me\in me∈m is an element, and ∗:M×M→M*:M\times M\rightarrow M∗:M×M→M is a function, such that the following conditions hold for all m,n,p∈Mm,n,p\in Mm,n,p∈M:

  • m∗e=mm*e=mm∗e=m
  • e∗m=me*m=me∗m=m
  • (m∗n)∗p=m∗(n∗p)(m*n)*p=m*(n*p)(m∗n)∗p=m∗(n∗p)

We refer to eee as the identity element and to ∗*∗ as the multiplication formula for the monoid. We call the first two rules identity laws and the third rule the associativity law for monoids.

Example (Trivial monoid) There is a monoid with only one element, M=({e},e,∗)M=(\{e\},e,*)M=({e},e,∗) where ∗:(e,e)→e*:(e,e)\rightarrow e∗:(e,e)→e. We call this monoid the trivial monoid and sometimes denoted it 1‾\underline{1}1​/

Definition

Let XXX be a set. A list in XXX is a pair (n,f)(n,f)(n,f) where n∈Nn\in\mathbb{N}n∈N is a natural number (called the length of the list) and f:n‾→Xf:\underline{n}\rightarrow Xf:n​→X is a function. We may denote such a list by

(n,f)=[f(1),f(2),...,f(n)](n,f)=[f(1),f(2),...,f(n)] (n,f)=[f(1),f(2),...,f(n)]

Given two lists L=(n,f),L′=(n′,f′)L=(n,f),L'=(n',f')L=(n,f),L′=(n′,f′), the concatenation of LLL and L′L'L′ is denoted L++L′=(n+n′,f++f′)L++L'=(n+n',f++f')L++L′=(n+n′,f++f′). The behavior of f++f′:n+n′‾→Xf++f':\underline{n+n'}\rightarrow Xf++f′:n+n′​→X is natural:

(f++f′)(i):={f(i)i≤nf′(i−n)i≥n+1(f++f')(i):=\begin{cases}f(i)&i\leq n\\f'(i-n)&i\geq n+1\end{cases} (f++f′)(i):={f(i)f′(i−n)​i≤ni≥n+1​

Definition(Free monoid)

Let XXX be a set. The free monoid generated by XXX is the sequence M:=(List(X),[],++)M:=(List(X),[],++)M:=(List(X),[],++), where List(X)List(X)List(X) is the set of lists of elements in XXX. We refer to XXX as the set of generators for the monoid MMM.

Definition(Presented monoid)

Let GGG be a finite set, and nnn be a natural number, and for each 1≤i≤n1\leq i\leq n1≤i≤n, let mim_imi​ and mi′m_i'mi′​ be elements of List(G)List(G)List(G). The monoid presented by generators GGG and relations {(mi,mi′)∣1≤i≤n}\{(m_i,m_i')|1\leq i\leq n\}{(mi​,mi′​)∣1≤i≤n} is the monoid M=(M,e,∗)\mathcal{M}=(M,e,*)M=(M,e,∗) defined as follows:

  • Let ∼\sim∼ denote the equivalence relation on List(G)List(G)List(G) generated by \
  • define M=List(G)/∼M=List(G)/\simM=List(G)/∼
  • e=[]e=[]e=[]
  • ∗*∗ is concatenating lists.

Example: Let G={a,b,c,d}G=\{a,b,c,d\}G={a,b,c,d} representing four buttons that can be pressed. The free monoid List(G)List(G)List(G) is the set of all ways of pressing buttons, like [a,a,c,c,d][a,a,c,c,d][a,a,c,c,d] means you push button aaa, then aaa, then ccc, then ccc, then ddd.

But when you notice that you press [a,a,c][a,a,c][a,a,c] is always equivalent to [d,d][d,d][d,d], and you press [a,c,a,c][a,c,a,c][a,c,a,c] is actually doing nothing. So we can have relation:

([a,a,c],[d,d]),([a,c,a,c],[])([a,a,c],[d,d]),([a,c,a,c],[]) ([a,a,c],[d,d]),([a,c,a,c],[])

So we can have the equivalent relation in Presented monoid:

[b,c,b,d,d,a,c,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,a,c,a,c,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,d,d,d][b,c,b,d,d,a,c,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,a,c,a,c,a,a,c,d]=\\ [b,c,b,a,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,d,d,d] [b,c,b,d,d,a,c,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,a,c,a,c,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,a,a,c,d]=[b,c,b,a,d,d,d]

Definition

A monoid is called cyclic if it has a representation involving only one generator, In other words, ∣G∣=1|G|=1∣G∣=1.

Example: Consider the monoid where G={a}G=\{a\}G={a} and the relation is empty. We get the additive monoid of natural numbers now since [a,a]++[a]=[a,a,a][a,a]++[a]=[a,a,a][a,a]++[a]=[a,a,a]. With the really strong relation [a]∼[][a]\sim [][a]∼[] we would get the trivial monoid having only one element [][][].

# Monoid actions

Definition (Monoid action)

Let (M,e,∗)(M,e,*)(M,e,∗) be a monoid and let SSS be a set. An action of (M,e,∗)(M,e,*)(M,e,∗) on SSS, or simply an action of MMM on SSS or an MMM-action on SSS, is a function

↺:M×S→S\circlearrowleft:M\times S\rightarrow S ↺:M×S→S

such that the following conditions hold for all m,n∈Mm,n\in Mm,n∈M and all s∈Ss\in Ss∈S:

  • e↺s=se\circlearrowleft s = se↺s=s

  • m↺(n↺s)=(m∗n)↺sm\circlearrowleft(n\circlearrowleft s)=(m*n)\circlearrowleft sm↺(n↺s)=(m∗n)↺s

Remark: To be pedantic, we may rewrite ↺\circlearrowleft↺ as α\alphaα:

  • α(e,s)=s\alpha(e,s)=sα(e,s)=s
  • α(m,α(n,s))=α(m∗n,s)\alpha(m,\alpha(n,s))=\alpha(m*n,s)α(m,α(n,s))=α(m∗n,s)

Example: let S={0,1,2,...,11}S=\{0,1,2,...,11\}S={0,1,2,...,11} and N=(N,0,+)N=(\mathbb{N},0,+)N=(N,0,+) be the additive monoid of natural numbers. We define a function ↺\circlearrowleft↺:

n↺s=(n+s)%12n\circlearrowleft s = (n+s)\%12 n↺s=(n+s)%12

the function is an action on SSS.

Example: Let f:R→Rf:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}f:R→R be a differentiable function of which we want to find roots. Let x0x_0x0​ be a starting point, consider the Newton’s method:

xn+1=g(xn)=xn−f(xn)f′(xn)x_{n+1}=g(x_n)=x_n-\frac{f(x_n)}{f'(x_n)} xn+1​=g(xn​)=xn​−f′(xn​)f(xn​)​

This is a monoid M=(N,+,0)M=(\mathbb{N},+,0)M=(N,+,0) acting on a set R\mathbb{R}R. and function:

n↺x=gn(x)n\circlearrowleft x=g^n(x) n↺x=gn(x)

Example: Consider a monoid MMM generated by the set {u,d,r}\{u,d,r\}{u,d,r} standing for “up,down,right” and subject to the relations:

[u,d]∼[][d,u]∼[][u,r]∼[r,u][d,r]∼[r,d][u,d]\sim[]\quad[d,u]\sim[]\quad[u,r]\sim [r,u]\quad[d,r]\sim[r,d] [u,d]∼[][d,u]∼[][u,r]∼[r,u][d,r]∼[r,d]

We may think the monoid acts on the set of positions. so “a list of movements + a position = a position” is the action.

Proposition: Let Σ,S\Sigma,SΣ,S be finite non-empty sets. Giving a function δ:Σ×S→S\delta:\Sigma\times S\rightarrow Sδ:Σ×S→S is equivalent to giving an action of the free monoid List(Σ)List(\Sigma)List(Σ) on SSS.

Proof: As matter of fact, we just need to prove that:

HomSet(List(Σ)×S,S)→≅HomSet(Σ×S,S)Hom_{Set}(List(\Sigma)\times S,S)\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow}Hom_{Set}(\Sigma\times S,S) HomSet​(List(Σ)×S,S)→≅HomSet​(Σ×S,S)

Let’s define:

ψ:HomSet(Σ×S,S)→HomSet(List(Σ)×S,S)ψ(f):List(Σ)×S→Sψ(f)(L,q)={qL=[]ψ(f)(L′,f(a,q))L=a::L′ϕ:HomSet(List(Σ)×S,S)→HomSet(Σ×S,S)ϕ(g):Σ×S→Sϕ(g)(a,q)=g([a],q)\psi:Hom_{Set}(\Sigma\times S,S)\rightarrow Hom_{Set}(List(\Sigma)\times S,S)\\ \psi(f):List(\Sigma)\times S\rightarrow S\\ \psi(f)(L,q)=\begin{cases} q&L=[]\\ \psi(f)(L',f(a,q))& L=a::L' \end{cases}\\ \phi:Hom_{Set}(List(\Sigma)\times S,S)\rightarrow Hom_{Set}(\Sigma\times S,S)\\ \phi(g):\Sigma\times S\rightarrow S\\ \phi(g)(a,q)=g([a],q) ψ:HomSet​(Σ×S,S)→HomSet​(List(Σ)×S,S)ψ(f):List(Σ)×S→Sψ(f)(L,q)={qψ(f)(L′,f(a,q))​L=[]L=a::L′​ϕ:HomSet​(List(Σ)×S,S)→HomSet​(Σ×S,S)ϕ(g):Σ×S→Sϕ(g)(a,q)=g([a],q)

Obviously we have ψ∘ϕ=id\psi\circ \phi=idψ∘ϕ=id and ϕ∘ψ=id\phi\circ\psi=idϕ∘ψ=id.

So:

"A finite state machine is an action of a free monoid on a finite set."

# Monoid homomorphism

Definition (Monoid homomorphism)

Let M=(M,e,∗)\mathcal{M}=(M,e,*)M=(M,e,∗) and M′=(M′,e′,∗′)\mathcal{M}'=(M',e',*')M′=(M′,e′,∗′) be monoids. A monoid homomorphism fff from M\mathcal{M}M to M′\mathcal{M}'M′, denoted f:M→M′f:\mathcal{M}\rightarrow\mathcal{M}'f:M→M′, is a function f:M→M′f:M\rightarrow M'f:M→M′, satisfying:

  • f(e)=e′f(e)=e'f(e)=e′
  • f(m1∗m2)=f(m1)∗′f(m2)f(m_1*m_2)=f(m_1)*'f(m_2)f(m1​∗m2​)=f(m1​)∗′f(m2​)

The set of monoid homomorphisms from M\mathcal{M}M to M′\mathcal{M}'M′ is denoted HomMon(M,M′)Hom_{Mon}(\mathcal{M},\mathcal{M}')HomMon​(M,M′).

Example: Given any monoid M\mathcal{M}M there is a unique monoid homomorphism from M\mathcal{M}M to the trivial monoid 1‾\underline{1}1​. There is also a unique homomorphism 1‾→M\underline{1}\rightarrow\mathcal{M}1​→M. These facts together have an upshot: we can always construct a homomorphism:

M→!1‾→!M′\mathcal{M}\stackrel{!}{\rightarrow}\underline{1}\stackrel{!}{\rightarrow }\mathcal{M}' M→!1​→!M′

which we call the trivial homomorphism.

Proposition: Let M=(Z,0,+)\mathcal{M}=(\mathbb{Z},0,+)M=(Z,0,+) and M′=(N,0,+)\mathcal{M'}=(\mathbb{N},0,+)M′=(N,0,+). The only monoid homomorphism f:M→M′f:\mathcal{M}\rightarrow\mathcal{M}'f:M→M′ sends every element m∈Zm\in\mathbb{Z}m∈Z to 0∈N0\in\mathbb{N}0∈N.

Proof:

0=f(0)=f(1+(−1))=f(1)+f(−1)∵f(1),f(−1)∈N,f(1)+f(−1)=0∴f(1)=f(−1)=00=f(0)=f(1+(-1))=f(1)+f(-1)\\ \because f(1),f(-1)\in\mathbb{N},f(1)+f(-1)=0\\ \therefore f(1)=f(-1)=0 0=f(0)=f(1+(−1))=f(1)+f(−1)∵f(1),f(−1)∈N,f(1)+f(−1)=0∴f(1)=f(−1)=0

Similarly, f(x)≡0f(x)\equiv 0f(x)≡0.

Proposition: Let GGG be a set, let F(G)=(List(G),[],++)F(G)=(List(G),[],++)F(G)=(List(G),[],++) be the free monoid on GGG, and let M=(M,e,∗)\mathcal{M}=(M,e,*)M=(M,e,∗) be any monoid. There is a natural bijection:

HomMon(F(G),M)→≅HomSet(G,M)Hom_{Mon}(F(G),\mathcal{M})\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow}Hom_{Set}(G,M) HomMon​(F(G),M)→≅HomSet​(G,M)

Proof: We construct

ϕ:HomMon(F(G),M)→HomSet(G,M)ϕ(f)(g)=f([g])ψ:HomSet(G,M)→HomMon(F(G),M)ψ(p)([g1,...,gn])=p(g1)∗...∗p(gn)ψ(p)([])=e\phi:Hom_{Mon}(F(G),\mathcal{M})\rightarrow Hom_{Set}(G,M)\\ \phi(f)(g)=f([g])\\ \psi:Hom_{Set}(G,M)\rightarrow Hom_{Mon}(F(G),\mathcal{M})\\ \psi(p)([g_1,...,g_n])=p(g_1)*...*p(g_n)\\ \psi(p)([])=e ϕ:HomMon​(F(G),M)→HomSet​(G,M)ϕ(f)(g)=f([g])ψ:HomSet​(G,M)→HomMon​(F(G),M)ψ(p)([g1​,...,gn​])=p(g1​)∗...∗p(gn​)ψ(p)([])=e

Then

ψ(ϕ(f))(L)=(ϕ(f)(g1)∗...∗ϕ(f)(gn))=f([g1])∗...∗f([gn])=f([g1]++...++[gn])=f(L)\psi(\phi(f))(L)=(\phi(f)(g_1)*...*\phi(f)(g_n))=f([g_1])*...*f([g_n])\\ =f([g_1]++...++[g_n])=f(L)\\ ψ(ϕ(f))(L)=(ϕ(f)(g1​)∗...∗ϕ(f)(gn​))=f([g1​])∗...∗f([gn​])=f([g1​]++...++[gn​])=f(L)

vice versa.

Proposition: Let M=(M,e,∗)\mathcal{M}=(M,e,*)M=(M,e,∗) and M′=(M′,e′,∗′)\mathcal{M}'=(M',e',*')M′=(M′,e′,∗′) be monoids, f:M→M′f:\mathcal{M}\rightarrow\mathcal{M}'f:M→M′ a monoid homomorphism, SSS a set, and suppose that α:M′×S→S\alpha:M'\times S\rightarrow Sα:M′×S→S is an action of M′\mathcal{M}'M′ on SSS. Then Δf(α):M×S→S\Delta_f(\alpha):M\times S\rightarrow SΔf​(α):M×S→S, defined as:

Δf(α)(m,s)=α(f(m),s)∈S\Delta_f(\alpha)(m,s)=\alpha(f(m),s)\in S Δf​(α)(m,s)=α(f(m),s)∈S

is a M\mathcal{M}M-monoid action on SSS.

Proof: as easy as a pie.

# Groups

Definition (Group)

Let (M,e,∗)(M,e,*)(M,e,∗) be a monoid. An element m∈Mm\in Mm∈M is said to have an inverse if there exists an m′∈Mm'\in Mm′∈M such that mm′=emm'=emm′=e and m′m=em'm=em′m=e. A group is a monoid in which every element m∈Mm\in Mm∈M has an inverse.

Proposition: The inverse element is unique.

Definition (Group action)

Let (G,e,∗)(G,e,*)(G,e,∗) be a group and SSS a set. An action of GGG on SSS is a function:

↺:G×S→S\circlearrowleft:G\times S\rightarrow S ↺:G×S→S

such that for all s∈Ss\in Ss∈S and g,g′∈Gg,g'\in Gg,g′∈G, we have

  • e↺s=se\circlearrowleft s=se↺s=s
  • g↺(g′↺s)=(g∗g′)↺sg\circlearrowleft(g'\circlearrowleft s)=(g*g')\circlearrowleft sg↺(g′↺s)=(g∗g′)↺s.

Definition(orbit)

Let GGG be a group acting on a set XXX. For any point x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, the orbit of xxx, denoted GxGxGx, is the set

Gx:={x′∈X∣∃g∈G,g↺x=x′}Gx:=\{x'\in X|\exists g\in G,g\circlearrowleft x=x'\} Gx:={x′∈X∣∃g∈G,g↺x=x′}

Definition

Let GGG and G′G'G′ be groups. A group homomorphism f:G→G′f:G\rightarrow G'f:G→G′ is defined to be a monoid homomorphism.

# Graphs

Definition(Graph)

A graph consists of a sequence G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt):

  • VVV is a set, called the set of vertices.
  • AAA is a set, called the set of arrows.
  • src:A→Vsrc:A\rightarrow Vsrc:A→V is a function, called the source function.
  • tgt:A→Vtgt:A\rightarrow Vtgt:A→V is a function, called the target function.

Definition(Path)

Let G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt) be a graph. A path of length nnn in GGG, denoted p∈PathG(n)p\in Path^{(n)}_Gp∈PathG(n)​ is a head-to-tail sequence

p=(v0→a1v1→a2v2→a3...→anvn)p=(v_0\stackrel{a_1}{\rightarrow}v_1\stackrel{a_2}{\rightarrow}v_2\stackrel{a_3}{\rightarrow}...\stackrel{a_n}{\rightarrow}v_n) p=(v0​→a1​v1​→a2​v2​→a3​...→an​vn​)

of arrows in GGG, which we denote by v0a1a2...anv_0a_1a_2...a_nv0​a1​a2​...an​. In particular we have canonical isomorphism PathG(1)≅APath^{(1)}_G\cong APathG(1)​≅A and PathG(0)≅VPath^{(0)}_G\cong VPathG(0)​≅V. And

PathG=⋃n∈NPathG(n)Path_G=\bigcup_{n\in\mathbb{N}}Path^{(n)}_G PathG​=n∈N⋃​PathG(n)​

we denote the source and the target vertex of a path by

srcˉ,tgtˉ:PathG→V\bar{src},\bar{tgt}:Path_G\rightarrow V srcˉ,tgtˉ​:PathG​→V

Definition

Let G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt) and G′=(V′,A′,src′,tgt′)G'=(V',A',src',tgt')G′=(V′,A′,src′,tgt′) be graphs. A graph homomorphism fff from GGG to G′G'G′, denoted f:G→G′f:G\rightarrow G'f:G→G′, consists of two functions f0:V→V′f_0:V\rightarrow V'f0​:V→V′ and f1:A→A′f_1:A\rightarrow A'f1​:A→A′ such that the two diagrams below commute:

# Orders

Definition(Order)

Let SSS be a set and R⊆S×SR\subseteq S\times SR⊆S×S a binary relation on SSS; if (s,s′)∈R(s,s')\in R(s,s′)∈R we will write s≤s′s\leq s's≤s′, then we say that RRR is a preorder if, for all s,s′,s′′∈Ss,s',s''\in Ss,s′,s′′∈S we have

  • s≤ss\leq ss≤s
  • if s≤s′s\leq s's≤s′ and s′≤s′′s'\leq s''s′≤s′′ then s≤s′′s\leq s''s≤s′′

If we want it to be a partial order, then we need to add

  • If s≤s′s\leq s's≤s′ and s′≤ss'\leq ss′≤s then s=s′s=s's=s′

If we want it to be a linear order, then we need to add

  • Either s≤s′s\leq s's≤s′ or s′≤ss'\leq ss′≤s.

Definition(clique)

Let (S,≤)(S,\leq)(S,≤) be a preorder. A clique is a subset S′⊆SS'\subseteq SS′⊆S such that for each a,b∈S′a,b\in S'a,b∈S′ one has a≤ba\leq ba≤b.

Definition(meet, join)

Let (S,≤)(S,\leq)(S,≤) be a preorder and let s,t∈Ss,t\in Ss,t∈S be elements. A meet of sss and ttt is an element w∈Sw\in Sw∈S satisfying

  • w≤sw\leq sw≤s and w≤tw\leq tw≤t
  • for any x∈Sx\in Sx∈S, if x≤sx\leq sx≤s and x≤tx\leq tx≤t then x≤wx\leq wx≤w

We write as w≅s∧tw\cong s\wedge tw≅s∧t.

A join of sss and ttt is an element w∈Sw\in Sw∈S satisfying

  • s≤ws\leq ws≤w and t≤wt\leq wt≤w
  • for any x∈Sx\in Sx∈S, if s≤xs\leq xs≤x and t≤xt\leq xt≤x then w≤xw\leq xw≤x

We write as w≅s∨tw\cong s\vee tw≅s∨t.

Definition(opposite order)

Let S=(S,≤)\mathcal{S}=(S,\leq)S=(S,≤) be a preorder. The opposite preorder, denoted Sop\mathcal{S}^{op}Sop is the preorder (S,≤op)(S,\leq^{op})(S,≤op) having the same set of elements but where s≤ops′s\leq^{op}s's≤ops′ iff s′≤ss'\leq ss′≤s.

Definition(opposite order)

Let S=(S,≤)\mathcal{S}=(S,\leq)S=(S,≤) and S′=(S′,≤′)\mathcal{S}'=(S',\leq')S′=(S′,≤′) be preorders, A morphism of preorders denoted f:S→S′f:\mathcal{S}\rightarrow\mathcal{S}'f:S→S′ is a function f:S→S′f:S\rightarrow S'f:S→S′ such that, for every pair of elements s1,s2∈Ss_1,s_2\in Ss1​,s2​∈S, if s1≤s2s_1\leq s_2s1​≤s2​ then f(s1)≤′f(s2)f(s_1)\leq'f(s_2)f(s1​)≤′f(s2​).

# Category theory

# categories and functors

Definition

A category C\mathcal{C}C is defined as follows: One announces some constituents (objects, morphisms, identities, compositions) and asserts (identity law, associativity law) that they conform to some laws. Specifically, one announces:

  1. a collection Ob(C)Ob(\mathcal{C})Ob(C), elements of which are called objects.

  2. for every pair x,y∈Ob(C)x,y\in Ob(\mathcal{C})x,y∈Ob(C), a set HomC(x,y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x,y)HomC​(x,y). It is called the hom-set from xxx to yyy; its elements are called morphisms from xxx to yyy.

  3. for every object x∈Ob(C)x\in Ob(\mathcal{C})x∈Ob(C), a specified morphism denoted idx∈HomC(x,x)id_x\in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x,x)idx​∈HomC​(x,x) called the identity morphism on xxx.

  4. for every three objects x,y,z∈Ob(C)x,y,z\in Ob(\mathcal{C})x,y,z∈Ob(C), a function

    ∘:HomC(y,z)×HomC(x,y)→HomC(x,z)\circ:Hom_{\mathcal{C}(y,z)}\times Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x,y)\rightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x,z) ∘:HomC(y,z)​×HomC​(x,y)→HomC​(x,z)

    called the composition formula.

Given objects x,y∈Ob(C)x,y\in Ob(\mathcal{C})x,y∈Ob(C), we can denote a morphism f∈HomC(x,y)f\in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x,y)f∈HomC​(x,y) by f:x→yf:x\rightarrow yf:x→y; we say that xxx is the domain of fff and that yyy is the codomain of fff. Given also g:y→zg:y\rightarrow zg:y→z, the composition formula is written using infix notation, so g∘f:x→zg\circ f:x\rightarrow zg∘f:x→z means ∘(g,f)∈HomC(x,z)\circ(g,f)\in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x,z)∘(g,f)∈HomC​(x,z).

  1. for every x,y∈Ob(C)x,y\in Ob(\mathcal{C})x,y∈Ob(C) and every morphism f:x→yf:x\rightarrow yf:x→y, we have

f∘idx=fidy∘f=ff\circ id_x = f\quad id_y\circ f = f f∘idx​=fidy​∘f=f

  1. if w,x,y,z,∈Ob(C)w,x,y,z,\in Ob(\mathcal{C})w,x,y,z,∈Ob(C) are any objects and f:w→x,g:x→yf:w\rightarrow x,g:x\rightarrow yf:w→x,g:x→y and h:y→zh:y\rightarrow zh:y→z are any morphisms, then the two ways to compose are the same:

(h∘g)∘f=h∘(g∘f)(h\circ g)\circ f=h\circ (g\circ f) (h∘g)∘f=h∘(g∘f)

Remark: Although we say Ob(C)Ob(\mathcal{C})Ob(C) is a collection of objects(that’s because sometimes we want to talk about set category, where all objects are sets), at the beginning of study, we still consider Ob(C)Ob(\mathcal{C})Ob(C) as a set.

Example: Inside the category Set is a subcategory Fin⊆\subseteq⊆Set, called the category of finite sets. Whereas an object S∈Ob(Set)S\in Ob(\textbf{Set})S∈Ob(Set) is a set that can have arbitrary cardinality, we define Fin such that its objects include all the sets SSS with finitely many elements, i.e. ∣S∣=n|S|=n∣S∣=n for some natural number nnn. Every object of Fin is an object of Set, but not vice versa. The morphisms are the same:

HomFin(S,S′)=HomSet(S,S′)Hom_{\textbf{Fin}}(S,S')=Hom_{\textbf{Set}}(S,S') HomFin​(S,S′)=HomSet​(S,S′)

Example(The category Mon of monoids): objects are monoids, and morphisms are the homomorphisms in monoids.

Example(The category Grp of groups): objects are groups, and morphisms are the homomorphisms in groups.

Example(The category PrO of preorders): objects are preorders, and morphisms are the homomorphisms in preorders.

Example(The category Grph of graphs): objects are graphs, and morphisms are the graph homomorphisms. Notice that since the left rectangular and the right rectangular commute, the whole diagram commutes.

So the associativity is ensured.

Definition(isomorphism)

Let C\mathcal{C}C be a category and let X,Y∈Ob(C)X,Y\in Ob(\mathcal{C})X,Y∈Ob(C) be objects. An isomorphism fff from XXX to YYY is a morphism f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y in C\mathcal{C}C, such that there exists a morphism g:Y→Xg:Y\rightarrow Xg:Y→X in C\mathcal{C}C such that

g∘f=idX,f∘g=idYg\circ f=id_X,f\circ g = id_Y g∘f=idX​,f∘g=idY​

In this case we say that the morphism fff is invertible and that ggg is the inverse of fff. We may also say that the objects XXX and YYY are isomorphic.

Lemma

Let C\mathcal{C}C be a category and let ∼\sim∼ be the relation on Ob(C)Ob(\mathcal{C})Ob(C) given by saying X∼YX\sim YX∼Y iff XXX and YYY are isomorphic. Then ∼\sim∼ is an equivalence relation.

Let’s consider another definition of category:

Definition

A category C\mathcal{C}C consists of a sequence (Ob(C),HomC,dom,cod,ids,∘)(Ob(\mathcal{C}),Hom_{\mathcal{C}},dom,cod,ids,\circ)(Ob(C),HomC​,dom,cod,ids,∘) where

  1. Ob(C)Ob(\mathcal{C})Ob(C) is a set
  2. HomCHom_{\mathcal{C}}HomC​ is a set, and dom,cod:HomC→Ob(C)dom,cod:Hom_\mathcal{C}\rightarrow Ob(\mathcal{C})dom,cod:HomC​→Ob(C) are functions
  3. ids:Ob(C)→HomCids:Ob(\mathcal{C})\rightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{C}}ids:Ob(C)→HomC​ is a function
  4. ∘\circ∘ is a function as depicted in the commutative diagram below

Definition(functors)

Let C\mathcal{C}C and C′\mathcal{C}'C′ be categories. A functor FFF from C\mathcal{C}C to C′\mathcal{C}'C′, denoted F:C→C′F:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{C}'F:C→C′, is defined as follows: One announces some constituents and asserts that they conform to some laws. Specifically, one announces

  1. a function Ob(F):Ob(C)→Ob(C′)Ob(F):Ob(\mathcal{C})\rightarrow Ob(\mathcal{C}')Ob(F):Ob(C)→Ob(C′) which we sometimes denote simply by F:Ob(C)→Ob(C′)F:Ob(\mathcal{C})\rightarrow Ob(\mathcal{C}')F:Ob(C)→Ob(C′)

  2. for every pair of objects c,d∈Ob(C)c,d\in Ob(\mathcal{C})c,d∈Ob(C), a function

    HomF(c,d):HomC(c,d)→HomC′(F(c),F(d))Hom_F(c,d):Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c,d)\rightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{C}'}(F(c),F(d)) HomF​(c,d):HomC​(c,d)→HomC′​(F(c),F(d))

    which we sometimes denote simply by F:HomC(c,d)→HomC′(F(c),F(d))F:Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c,d)\rightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{C}'}(F(c),F(d))F:HomC​(c,d)→HomC′​(F(c),F(d)).

One asserts that the following laws hold:

  1. Identities are preserved by FFF:

    F(idc)=idF(c)F(id_c)=id_{F(c)} F(idc​)=idF(c)​

  2. Composition is preserved by FFF:

    F(h∘g)=F(h)∘F(g)F(h\circ g)=F(h)\circ F(g) F(h∘g)=F(h)∘F(g)

Example: Consider the functor:

U:Mon→SetU:\textbf{Mon}\rightarrow\textbf{Set} U:Mon→Set

Which means every monoid has a underlying set, and every homomorphisms between monoids has a corresponding function between sets.

Proposition: Let PrO be the category of preorders and Grph be the category of graphs. There is function P:PrO→GrphP:\textbf{PrO}\rightarrow\textbf{Grph}P:PrO→Grph such that for any preorder X=(X,≤)\mathcal{X}=(X,\leq)X=(X,≤), the graph P(X)P(\mathcal{X})P(X) has vertices XXX.

Proposition: There exists a category, called the category of small categories and denoted Cat, in which the objects are the small categories and the morphisms are the functors:

HomCat(C,D)={F:C→D∣F  is  a  functor}Hom_{Cat}(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D})=\{F:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}|F\;is\;a\;functor\} HomCat​(C,D)={F:C→D∣Fisafunctor}

# Categories and functors commonly arising in mathematics

# Monoids as categories

Let (M,e,∗)(M,e,*)(M,e,∗) be a monoid. We consider it as a category M\mathcal{M}M with one object, Ob(M)={Δ}Ob(\mathcal{M})=\{\Delta\}Ob(M)={Δ}, and

HomM(Δ,Δ)=MHom_{\mathcal{M}}(\Delta,\Delta)=M HomM​(Δ,Δ)=M

The identity morphism idΔid_{\Delta}idΔ​ serves as the monoid identity eee, and the composition formula

∘:HomM(Δ,Δ)×HomM(Δ,Δ)→HomM(Δ,Δ)\circ:Hom_{\mathcal{M}}(\Delta,\Delta)\times Hom_{\mathcal{M}}(\Delta,\Delta)\rightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{M}}(\Delta,\Delta) ∘:HomM​(Δ,Δ)×HomM​(Δ,Δ)→HomM​(Δ,Δ)

is given by ∗:M×M→M*:M\times M\rightarrow M∗:M×M→M. The associativity and identity laws for the monoid match precisely with the associativity and identity for categories.

The homomorphism between two monoids can be interpreted as the functor between two one-object categories.

"A monoid is a category with one object. A monoid homomorphism is just a functor between one-object categories."

Theorem:

There is a functor i:Mon→Cati:\textbf{Mon}\rightarrow\textbf{Cat}i:Mon→Cat with the following properties:

  • for every monoid M∈Ob(Mon)\mathcal{M}\in Ob(\textbf{Mon})M∈Ob(Mon), the category i(M)∈Ob(Cat)i(\mathcal{M})\in Ob(\textbf{Cat})i(M)∈Ob(Cat) itself has exactly one object.

  • for every pair of monoids M,M′∈Ob(Mon)\mathcal{M},\mathcal{M'}\in Ob(\textbf{Mon})M,M′∈Ob(Mon) the function

    HomMon(M,M′)→≅HomCat(i(M),i(M′))Hom_{\textbf{Mon}}(\mathcal{M},\mathcal{M}')\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow}Hom_{\textbf{Cat}}(i(\mathcal{M}),i(\mathcal{M}')) HomMon​(M,M′)→≅HomCat​(i(M),i(M′))

    induced by the functor iii, is a bijection.

Example: Let C\mathcal{C}C be a category and x∈Ob(C)x\in Ob(\mathcal{C})x∈Ob(C) an object. Let M=HomC(x,x)M=Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x,x)M=HomC​(x,x). Note that for any two elements f,g∈mf,g\in mf,g∈m we have f∘g∈Mf\circ g\in Mf∘g∈M. Let M=(M,idx,∘)\mathcal{M}=(M,id_x,\circ)M=(M,idx​,∘). It is easy to check that M\mathcal{M}M is a monoid; it is called the endomorphism monoid of xxx in C\mathcal{C}C.

# Groups as categories

"A group is a category with one object, such that every morphism is an isomorphism. A group homomorphism is just a functor between such categories"

Theorem:

There is a functor i:Grp→Cati:\textbf{Grp}\rightarrow\textbf{Cat}i:Grp→Cat with the following properties

  • for every group G∈Ob(Grp)\mathcal{G}\in Ob(\textbf{Grp})G∈Ob(Grp), the category i(G)∈Ob(Cat)i(\mathcal{G})\in Ob(\textbf{Cat})i(G)∈Ob(Cat) itself has exactly one object, and every morphism in i(G)i(\mathcal{G})i(G) is an isomorphism

  • for every pair of groups G,G′∈Ob(Grp)\mathcal{G,G}'\in Ob(\textbf{Grp})G,G′∈Ob(Grp) the function

    HomGrp(G,G′)→≅HomCat(i(G),i(G′))Hom_{\textbf{Grp}}(\mathcal{G},\mathcal{G}')\stackrel{\cong}{\rightarrow}Hom_{\textbf{Cat}}(i(\mathcal{G}),i(\mathcal{G}')) HomGrp​(G,G′)→≅HomCat​(i(G),i(G′))

    induced by the functor iii, is a bijection.

# Preorders as categories

A preorder (X,≤)(X,\leq)(X,≤) consists of a set XXX and a binary relation. We can make from (X,≤)∈Ob(PrO)(X,\leq)\in Ob(\textbf{PrO})(X,≤)∈Ob(PrO) a category X∈Ob(Cat)\mathcal{X}\in Ob(\textbf{Cat})X∈Ob(Cat) as follows. Define Ob(X)=XOb(\mathcal{X})=XOb(X)=X and for every two objects x,y∈Xx,y\in Xx,y∈X:

HomX(x,y)={{"x≤y"}x≤y∅x≰yHom_{\mathcal{X}}(x,y)=\begin{cases} \{"x\leq y"\}&x\leq y\\ \emptyset & x\not\leq y \end{cases} HomX​(x,y)={{"x≤y"}∅​x≤yx≤y​

Theorem:

There is a functor i:PrO→Cati:\textbf{PrO}\rightarrow\textbf{Cat}i:PrO→Cat with the following properties

  • the category X=i(X,≤)\mathcal{X}=i(X,\leq)X=i(X,≤) has objects Ob(X)=XOb(\mathcal{X})=XOb(X)=X.
  • for each pair of elements x,x′∈Ob(X)x,x'\in Ob(\mathcal{X})x,x′∈Ob(X) the set HomX(x,x′)Hom_{\mathcal{X}}(x,x')HomX​(x,x′) has at most one element.

"A preorder is a category in which every hom-set has either 0 or 1 element. A preorder morphism is just a functor between such categories."

# Natural transformations

"Naturality works like this: Using a function f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y to convert a list of lists of XXX's into a list of list of YYY's and then concatenating to get a simple list of YYY's does the same thing as first concatenating our list of lists of XXX's into a simple list of XXX's and then using our function fff to convert it into a list of YYY's***"***.

Example: Let X={a,b,c}X=\{a,b,c\}X={a,b,c} and Y={1,2,3}Y=\{1,2,3\}Y={1,2,3} and let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y assign f(a)=1,f(b)=1,f(c)=2f(a)=1,f(b)=1,f(c)=2f(a)=1,f(b)=1,f(c)=2. Our naturality condition says the following for any list of lists of XXX's, in particular for [[a,b],[a,c,a,b,c],[c]][[a,b],[a,c,a,b,c],[c]][[a,b],[a,c,a,b,c],[c]]:

Keep these μX\mu_XμX​ in mind in the following definition – they serve as the “components” of a natural transformation List∘List→ListList\circ List\rightarrow ListList∘List→List of functors C→D\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}C→D, where C=D=Set\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{D}=\textbf{Set}C=D=Set.

Definition

Let C\mathcal{C}C and D\mathcal{D}D be categories and let F:C→DF:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}F:C→D and G:C→DG:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}G:C→D be functors. A natural transformation α\alphaα from FFF to GGG, denoted α:F→G\alpha:F\rightarrow Gα:F→G, is defined as follows: one announces some constituents and asserts they conform to some laws. Specifically, one announces:

  1. For each object c∈Ob(C)c\in Ob(\mathcal{C})c∈Ob(C) a morphism αc:F(c)→G(c)\alpha_c:F(c)\rightarrow G(c)αc​:F(c)→G(c) in D\mathcal{D}D, called the c-component of α\alphaα.

One asserts that the following law holds:

  1. For every morphism h:c→c′h:c\rightarrow c'h:c→c′ in C\mathcal{C}C, the following square, called the naturality square for hhh, must commute:

Example: Consider the categories C≅[1]\mathcal{C}\cong[1]C≅[1] and D≅[2]\mathcal{D}\cong[2]D≅[2] drawn below:

Consider the functors F,G:[1]→[2]F,G:[1]\rightarrow [2]F,G:[1]→[2] where

F(0)=A,F(1)=BG(0)=A,G(1)=CF(0)=A,F(1)=B\\ G(0)=A,G(1)=C F(0)=A,F(1)=BG(0)=A,G(1)=C

Then the naturality square for hhh, the only morphism in C\mathcal{C}C, is

Of course it commutes.

Lemma:

Let C\mathcal{C}C and D\mathcal{D}D be categories, let F,G:C→DF,G:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}F,G:C→D be functors, and for every object c∈Ob(C)c\in Ob(\mathcal{C})c∈Ob(C), let αc:F(c)→G(c)\alpha_c:F(c)\rightarrow G(c)αc​:F(c)→G(c) be a morphism in D\mathcal{D}D. Suppose given a path

c0→f1c1→f2...→fncnc_0\stackrel{f_1}{\rightarrow}c_1\stackrel{f_2}{\rightarrow}...\stackrel{f_n}{\rightarrow}c_n c0​→f1​c1​→f2​...→fn​cn​

such that the naturality square

commutes for each 1≤i≤n1\leq i\leq n1≤i≤n. Then the naturality square for the composite p=fn∘...∘f2∘f1:c0→cnp=f_n\circ...\circ f_2\circ f_1:c_0\rightarrow c_np=fn​∘...∘f2​∘f1​:c0​→cn​

also commutes.

In particular, when n=0, it means that the naturality square commutes for every identity morphism idcid_cidc​.

The proof is quite self-evident…since the functors require to preserve associativity:

F(f1∘f2)=F(f1)∘F(f2)F(f_1\circ f_2)=F(f_1)\circ F(f_2) F(f1​∘f2​)=F(f1​)∘F(f2​)

# Vertical and horizontal composition

Proposition: Let C\mathcal{C}C and D\mathcal{D}D be categories. There exists a category, called the category of functors from C\mathcal{C}C to D\mathcal{D}D and denoted Fun(C,D)Fun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D})Fun(C,D), whose objects are the functors C→D\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}C→D and whose morphisms are the natural transformations,

HomFun(C,D))(F,G)={α:F→G∣α  is  a  natural  transformation}Hom_{Fun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D}))}(F,G)=\{\alpha:F\rightarrow G|\alpha\;is\;a\;natural\;transformation\} HomFun(C,D))​(F,G)={α:F→G∣αisanaturaltransformation}

We sometimes denote the category Fun(C,D)Fun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D})Fun(C,D) by DC\mathcal{D}^\mathcal{C}DC.

Lemma

Let C\mathcal{C}C and D\mathcal{D}D be categories and let F,G:C→DF,G:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}F,G:C→D be functors. A natural transformation α:F→G\alpha:F\rightarrow Gα:F→G is an isomorphism in Fun(C,D)Fun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D})Fun(C,D) if and only if the component αc:F(c)→G(c)\alpha_c:F(c)\rightarrow G(c)αc​:F(c)→G(c) is an isomorphism for each object c∈Ob(C)c\in Ob(\mathcal{C})c∈Ob(C). In this case α\alphaα is called a natural isomorphism.

Proof: First suppose that α\alphaα is an isomorphism with inverse β:G→F\beta:G\rightarrow Fβ:G→F, and let βc:G(c)→F(c)\beta_c:G(c)\rightarrow F(c)βc​:G(c)→F(c) denote its ccc component. We know that α∘β=idG\alpha\circ\beta=id_Gα∘β=idG​ and β∘α=idF\beta\circ\alpha=id_Fβ∘α=idF​. So for every c∈Ob(C)c\in Ob(\mathcal{C})c∈Ob(C), αc∘βc=idG(c)\alpha_c\circ\beta_c=id_{G(c)}αc​∘βc​=idG(c)​ and βc∘αc=idF(c)\beta_c\circ\alpha_c=id_{F(c)}βc​∘αc​=idF(c)​. So αc\alpha_cαc​ is an isomorphism.

Second suppose that each αc\alpha_cαc​ is an isomorphism with inverse βc\beta_cβc​. We need to see that these components assemble into a natural transformation, i.e. the right square commutes:

We have

F(h)∘βc=βc′∘αc′∘F(h)∘βc=βc′∘G(h)∘αc∘βc=βc′∘G(h)F(h)\circ \beta_c=\beta_{c'}\circ\alpha_{c'}\circ F(h)\circ\beta_c=\beta_{c'}\circ G(h)\circ\alpha_c\circ\beta_c=\beta_{c'}\circ G(h) F(h)∘βc​=βc′​∘αc′​∘F(h)∘βc​=βc′​∘G(h)∘αc​∘βc​=βc′​∘G(h)

Qed.

Definition(Whiskering)

Let B,C,D\mathcal{B,C,D}B,C,D and E\mathcal{E}E be categories, let G1,G2:C→DG_1,G_2:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}G1​,G2​:C→D be functors, and let α:G1→G2\alpha:G_1\rightarrow G_2α:G1​→G2​ a natural transformation. Suppose that F:B→CF:\mathcal{B}\rightarrow\mathcal{C}F:B→C is a functor (respectively H:D→EH:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{E}H:D→E), depicted below:

Then the pre-whiskering of α\alphaα by FFF, denoted α⋄F:G1∘F→G2∘F\alpha\diamond F:G_1\circ F\rightarrow G_2\circ Fα⋄F:G1​∘F→G2​∘F (respectively, the post-whiskering of α\alphaα by HHH, denoted H⋄α:H∘G1→H∘G2H\diamond\alpha:H\circ G_1\rightarrow H\circ G_2H⋄α:H∘G1​→H∘G2​) is defined as follows:

For each b∈Ob(B)b\in Ob(\mathcal{B})b∈Ob(B) the component (α⋄F)b:G1∘F(b)→G2∘F(b)(\alpha\diamond F)_b:G_1\circ F(b)\rightarrow G_2\circ F(b)(α⋄F)b​:G1​∘F(b)→G2​∘F(b) is defined to be αF(b)\alpha_{F(b)}αF(b)​. (Respectively, for each c∈Ob(C)c\in Ob(\mathcal{C})c∈Ob(C) the component (H⋄α)c:H∘G1(c)→H∘G2(c)(H\diamond\alpha)_c:H\circ G_1(c)\rightarrow H\circ G_2(c)(H⋄α)c​:H∘G1​(c)→H∘G2​(c) is defined to be H(α)H(\alpha)H(α).) Checking that the naturality squares is straightforward.

Definition

Let B,C\mathcal{B,C}B,C and D\mathcal{D}D be categories, let F1,F2:B→CF_1,F_2:\mathcal{B}\rightarrow\mathcal{C}F1​,F2​:B→C and G1,G2:C→DG_1,G_2:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}G1​,G2​:C→D be functors, and let α:F1→F2\alpha:F_1\rightarrow F_2α:F1​→F2​ and β:G1→G2\beta:G_1\rightarrow G_2β:G1​→G2​ be natural transformations, as depicted below:

By pre- and post-whiskering in one order or the other we get the following diagram

It is straightforward to show that this diagram commutes, so we can take the composition to be our definition of the horizontal composition

β⋄α:G1∘F1→G2∘F2\beta\diamond\alpha:G_1\circ F_1\rightarrow G_2\circ F_2 β⋄α:G1​∘F1​→G2​∘F2​

Theorem:

Given a setup of categories, functors, and natural transformations as above, we have

(β2∘β1)⋄(α2∘α1)=(β2⋄α2)∘(β1⋄α1)(\beta_2\circ\beta_1)\diamond(\alpha_2\circ\alpha_1)=(\beta_2\diamond\alpha_2)\circ(\beta_1\diamond\alpha_1) (β2​∘β1​)⋄(α2​∘α1​)=(β2​⋄α2​)∘(β1​⋄α1​)

Proof:

Page 158

# Database

# Basics

A database is a collection of tables, each table T of which consists of a set of columns and a set of rows.

The primary key column is tasked with uniquely identifying different rows, like the “ID” column in the left table.

The data columns house elementary data of a certain sort.

The foreign key columns link one table to another, creating a connection pattern between tables. Each foreign key column houses data that needs to be further unpacked. For example, the Source column is a foreign key to the supplier table.

What’s more, we could even say that data columns are specific kinds of foreign keys. That is, each data column constitutes a foreign key to some non-branching leaf table, which has no additional data.

# Schema

Consider the five tables following:

And the diagram:

The five tables from (3.13) and (3.15) are seen as five vertices.

The six foreign key columns from (3.13) and (3.15) are seen as six arrows, each points from a table to a foreign table.

The two rules below are seen as statements at the top of Display (3.16).

  • Rule1. For every employee eee, the manager of eee works in the same department that eee works in.
  • Rule2. For every department ddd, the secretary of ddd works in department ddd.

Think carefully about the diagram, then you can understand it quickly. Remember that there are only three types of columns: primary key column(ID), data columns (fist, last, name) and foreign key columns (manager, worksIn, secretary). And the element of foreign key columns is some table’s ID.

Definition

Let G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt) be a graph, and let PathGPath_GPathG​ denote the set of paths in GGG. A path equivalence declaration is an expression of the form p≃qp\simeq qp≃q where p,q∈PathGp,q\in Path_Gp,q∈PathG​ have the same source and target:

src(p)=src(q),tgt(p)=tgt(q)src(p)=src(q),tgt(p)=tgt(q) src(p)=src(q),tgt(p)=tgt(q)

A congruence on GGG is a relation ≃\simeq≃ on PathGPath_GPathG​ that has the following properties:

  1. The relation ≃\simeq≃ is an equivalence relation.
  2. If p≃qp\simeq qp≃q then src(p)=src(q)src(p)=src(q)src(p)=src(q).
  3. If p≃qp\simeq qp≃q then tgt(p)=tgt(q)tgt(p)=tgt(q)tgt(p)=tgt(q).
  4. Suppose p,q:b→qp,q:b\rightarrow qp,q:b→q are paths, and m:a→bm:a\rightarrow bm:a→b is an arrow. If p≃qp\simeq qp≃q then mp≃mqmp\simeq mqmp≃mq.
  5. Suppose p,q:a→bp,q:a\rightarrow bp,q:a→b are paths, and n:b→cn:b\rightarrow cn:b→c is an arrow. If p≃qp\simeq qp≃q then pn≃qnpn\simeq qnpn≃qn.

Any set of path equivalence declarations (PEDs) generates a congruence. We tend to elide the difference between a congruence and the set of PEDs that generates it.

Lemma

Suppose that GGG is a graph and ≃\simeq≃ is a congruence on GGG. Suppose p≃q:a→bp\simeq q:a\rightarrow bp≃q:a→b and r≃s:b→cr\simeq s:b\rightarrow cr≃s:b→c. Then pr≃qspr\simeq qspr≃qs.

Definition(Schema)

A database schema C\mathcal{C}C consists of a pair C=(G,≃)\mathcal{C}=(G,\simeq)C=(G,≃) where GGG is a graph and ≃\simeq≃ is a congruence on GGG.

Converting a schema C=(G,≃)\mathcal{C}=(G,\simeq)C=(G,≃) into a table layout should be done as follows:

  1. There should be a table for every vertex in GGG and if the vertex is named, the table should have that name.
  2. Each table should have a left-most column called ID, set apart from the other columns by a double vertical line.
  3. To each arrow aaa in GGG having source vertex s=src(a)s=src(a)s=src(a) and target vertex t=tgt(a)t=tgt(a)t=tgt(a), there should be a foreign key column aaa in table sss, referring to table ttt; if the arrow aaa is named column aaa should have that name.

# Instances

Definition(Instance)

Let C=(G,≃)\mathcal{C}=(G,\simeq)C=(G,≃) where G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt). An instance on C\mathcal{C}C, denoted (PL,FK):C→Set(PL,FK):\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\textbf{Set}(PL,FK):C→Set, is defined as follows: One announces some constituents and asserts that they conform to a law. Specifically, one announces:

  1. a function PK:V→SetPK:V\rightarrow\textbf{Set}PK:V→Set. i.e. to each vertex v∈Vv\in Vv∈V one provides a set PK(v)PK(v)PK(v)
  2. for every arrow a∈Aa\in Aa∈A with v=src(a)v=src(a)v=src(a) and w=tgt(a)w=tgt(a)w=tgt(a), a function FK(a):PK(v)→PK(w)FK(a):PK(v)\rightarrow PK(w)FK(a):PK(v)→PK(w).

One asserts that the following law holds for any vertices v,wv,wv,w and paths p=va1a2...amp=va_1a_2...a_mp=va1​a2​...am​ and q=va1′a2′...an′q=va_1'a_2'...a_n'q=va1′​a2′​...an′​ from vvv to www;

  1. If p≃qp\simeq qp≃q then for all x∈PK(v)x\in PK(v)x∈PK(v), we have

    FK(am)∘...∘FK(a1)(x)=FK(an′)∘...∘FK(a1′)(x)FK(a_m)\circ...\circ FK(a_1)(x)=FK(a_n')\circ...\circ FK(a_1')(x) FK(am​)∘...∘FK(a1​)(x)=FK(an′​)∘...∘FK(a1′​)(x)

    in PK(w)PK(w)PK(w).

# The category of instances on a database schema

Definition

Let C\mathcal{C}C be a schema (or category). The category of instances on C\mathcal{C}C, denoted C−Set\mathcal{C}-\textbf{Set}C−Set, is Fun(C,Set)Fun(\mathcal{C},\textbf{Set})Fun(C,Set). Its objects are C\mathcal{C}C-instances (i.e. functors C→Set\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\textbf{Set}C→Set) and its morphisms are natural transformations.

# Categories and schemas are equivalent

Firstly, let’s think about Paths. Paths can be viewed as a functor Grph→Grph\textbf{Grph}\rightarrow\textbf{Grph}Grph→Grph in that

Path(G)=(V,PathG,srcˉ,tgtˉ)∈Ob(Grph)Path(G)=(V,Path_G,\bar{src},\bar{tgt})\in Ob(\textbf{Grph}) Path(G)=(V,PathG​,srcˉ,tgtˉ​)∈Ob(Grph)

and given a graph homomorphism f:G→G′f:G\rightarrow G'f:G→G′, every path in GGG is sent under fff to a path in G′G'G′. So Paths is a functor.

Definition

Let G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt)G=(V,A,src,tgt) and G′=(V′,A′,src′,tgt′)G'=(V',A',src',tgt')G′=(V′,A′,src′,tgt′) be graphs, and let C=(G,≃G)\mathcal{C}=(G,\simeq_G)C=(G,≃G​) and D=(G′,≃G′)\mathcal{D}=(G',\simeq_{G'})D=(G′,≃G′​) be schemas. A schema morphism FFF from C\mathcal{C}C to D\mathcal{D}D, denoted F:C→DF:\mathcal{C}\rightarrow\mathcal{D}F:C→D is a graph homomorphism

F:G→Paths(G′)F:G\rightarrow Paths(G') F:G→Paths(G′)

that satisfies the following condition for any paths p,qp,qp,q in GGG:

if  p≃Gq  then  PathsF(p)≃G′PathsF(q)if\;p\simeq_Gq\;then\;Paths_{F}(p)\simeq_{G'}Paths_{F}(q) ifp≃G​qthenPathsF​(p)≃G′​PathsF​(q)
